div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passenegers to the ship.

The Brindial Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passenegrs can go on board the evening before. The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivnig in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is €22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
the Sea fares are:
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passenegers can embark at Port Said.

div.head: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1905.
SPAIN AND FRANCE
div.p: The safe arrival of M. Loubet at Madrid and his enthusiastic reception by the Madri- lenos, will be delight those many Frenchmen and Spaniards to whom a Latin League, or, at all events, a close reapprochment between the Latin nations, is a polticial ideal. THe rela- tions between France and Spain are now thoroughly friendly, and French capital, al- ready interested more than that of any other nation in the development of the Iberian Kingdom, is more and more inclined to aid the development of Spanish industry. Since the Spanish-Smerican war, which proved nothing short of a blessing to Spanish Finance, the various political parties of Spain have all been inclined to adopt a policy of economy and retrenchment, and no Spanish Minister who proposed, say, a forward policy in Morocco or an ambitious programme of new naval construction, would have much chance of support. Spain requires years of recuperation before she can again play a great part in the councils of the Powers. The question of land tenure and the tension be- tween the Clerical and the Liberal elements have to be settled. Spanish Agriculure, which may have a great future, requires the inagura- tion of an extensive programme of irrigation works; the great mineral resources of the country are only half developed, and new industries must be built up to replace those ruined by the loss of the Phillippines, Cuba, and Porto Rico. For these objects, internal and external peace and the assitance of foreign capital and required, and Spain has no ambi- tion to make history for a generation to come.

The geographical situation of Spain-indeed of the whole Iberian Peninsula- is such that a friendly understanding with the kingdoms of Spain and Portugal is of vital importance both to France and to England. A hostile Spain would to some extent neutralise Gibraltar, since vessels lying in the docks could be easily reached by the long-range howitzers and siege guns from Algesiras. A hostile cruiser or two using the Spanish ports of Ferrol and Vigo or the Canaries as its base might do an infinity of damage to the merchant shipping, and if Spain's friendship is valuable to England it is precious to France, which has a southern land frontier to defend and would suffer fro the use of Port Mahon as a hostile base. Though navally impotent for the present, Spain, by the mere fact of her position, might conceivably turn the scale in a naval war, and the fact that both France and England realise the importance of doing their utmost to arrive at a friendly understanding with the monarchy of King Alfonso XIII., is of good augury for the world's peace. England has by her support to Spain's Moroccean aspirations, which, though not exten- sive, are still important, done something to atine for her unnecessarily anti-Spanish atti- tude in the Spanish-American conflict; a determination to keep the ring clear was natural enough, but our sympathy need not have taken a form that wounded Spanish pride.

div.head: MOSCOW ISOLATED
div.p: the railway strike.
STRIKERS DETERMINED.
St. Petersburg, October 23.
All traffic between here and Moscow has ceased. The strikers are determined. The Minister Khilikoff vainly assigned for two hours with the engine-drivers at Moscow. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, October 23.
Owing to the general railway strike, the city of Moscow is entirely cut off from the rest of the empire. (Havas)

div.head: RUSSIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY. SOCIALIST ATTITUDE.
div.p: Warsaw, October 23.
The Socialist parties have unitedly issued a proclamation declaring forcibly that they will prevent the election of Deputies for tho National Assembly. (Reuter)

div.head: MANCHURIA. EVACUATION BY RUSSIANS.
div.p: Harbin, October 23.

All northward trains are loaded with troops and equipment belonging to the Russian Army, which is rapidly evacuating Manchuria, but many will be unable to move before winter. The Russians are extending their commercial activity to Dalny and Port Arthur. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPANESE NAVAL REVIEW. ENTHUSIASTIC CROWDS.
div.p: Enthusiastic crowds witnessed tho review of the 19th instant. The Emperor. on board the Asama, with Admiral Togo by his side, steam- ed between tho lines, which included ten Russian prizes. He afterwards received the British and American officers on board the Asama. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLAND, FRANCE, AND GERMANY. ACRIMONIOUS PRESS POLEMIC.
div.p: A recent article in the "None Freie Presse” accusing Lord Lansdowne of having prepared, with M. Delcasse, an Anglo-French war against Germany, lias caused a fresh acrimonious polemic between the German press, on one side, and that of Great Britain and France on the other.
The acerbity this dispute still keeps alive the international animosities excited by the “Matin." (Reuter)

div.head: PORTE ASSUMES OFFENSIVE. NOTE TO AUSTRIA.
div.p: The Porte, assuming the offensive, has sent the Austrian Embassy a note objecting to the presence of the international financial delega tion at Uskub, and pointing out that its inter- vention in internal affairs is prejudicial to Tarkish interests. The removal of the delega- tion is therefore requested. (Reuter)

div.head: M. LOUBET IN SPAIN. SPLENDID RECEPTION.
div.p: Madrid, October 23.
President Loubet and M. Rouvier have received a splendid reception. (Reuter)
Madrid, October 23.
M. Loubet: arrived in the afternoon.

The King received him at the station, and the people gave him a magnificent reception. At the banquet in the evening the King and M. Loubet drank toasts to the friendly rela- tions of France and Spain f adding that peace was the political object of both Governments. (Havas)

div.head: THE MOROCCO INCIDENT. OFFICERS WELL TREATED.
div.p: Tangier October 23.
The British officers state that they were well treated. The Cherif experienced no difficulty in effecting the exchange of primers. No indem- nity wass asked, and no conditions imposed. (Reuter)

div.head: COTTON TRADE DISPUTE.
div.p: Boston, October 23.
The Fall River operatives have rejected the manufacturers’ offer of an increase of five per pentum. (Reuter)

div.head: Stray Dogs.
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in Old Cairo during the night of Wednesday will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Smallpox
div.p: has made its appearance at Negouh, a village in the Esneh district, and sanitary measures have been prescribed.

div.head: Railway Coal Contract
div.p: We understand that Messrs. Pyman, Watson & Co., of Cardiff have secured the Egyptian State Railway contract for 310,000 tons of coal at 11s.3d. per ton f.o.b.

div.head: Egyptian Army Review
div.p: H E. the Sirdar will review the troops in Cairo at 7.20 a.m. to-morrow on the Observatory ground, when they will parade as strong as possible, and the cadets of the Military School will also attend. The Cavalry Band will attend dismounted, and the colours will be carried.

div.head: Popular University
div.p: Cavaliore Salvini has consented to recite some Italian poetry, including a song of Dante's, at the university to-morrow evening, commencing at 9.15 o’clock. Admission will be reserved to adherents of the university, who may obtain tickets on application to the secretariat to-day and to- morrow from 6 to 8 p.m.

Fifteen lads, sons of some sheikhs of the Yemen, have arrived at Alexandria and are staying at the Eikudar Hotel. They are proceeding to Constantinople, whore they will receive their education in “the Clans School (Maktab-al- Ashira), and intend leaving by the Khedivial mail steamer to-morrow. Among these lads there are four who lost their fathers doring the last sfiege of Sand*. The Maktab-ul-Ashira was established by H.M. the Sultan for the free education of members of the different clans living in the Ottoman Empire, viz., Charkess, Druses of Hauran, Kurds, Arabs, and Bedouins.

div.head: Mysterious Affair
div.p: M. Alexander Tasso, a Syrian resident of Alexandria, was found lying in a street in Moharrem Bey yesterday, with a stab wound in his abdomen and another in his head. He had been lying there for some hours, and on being questioned as to how he came by his wounds he explained that he was returning home on Sunday night, when he was assaulted by some unknown person. He had previously been drinking with some friends and, feeling drowsy as a consequence, he could not recognise his assailant. The motive of the crime was not theft, as M. Tasso still carried his watch and purse. His wounds are not considered very serious.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Djemil Pasha Toussoun arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles yesterday by the Norddeutacher Lloyd S.S. Schleswig.

H. E. Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, left to-day, with his civil and military household, for Cairo by special train, which left Hadra station at 1 9.20 a.m. and arrived at Cairo at 12.35 p.m.
H. M. the Sultan has conferred the rank of Wazara upon Aly Pasha, the new Cherif of Mecca.
The Grand Cadi has receri ed a spocial leave ' of twenty days in order to pay a visit to Constantinople.

Contrary to the announcement made by a Cairo contemporary, Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha did not leave for Khartoum on Saturday evening. Wo are informed that his Excellency has reserved a bed in the sleeping-car train which leaves for Luxor to-morrow evening, and that be will be accompanied by CoL Stanton Bey and several officers of the Egyptian Army. The International Sleeping and Restaurant Car Company have arranged to attach a special restaurant car to the Luxor-Assouan train on the following day, for Slatin Pasha and his party.
Yecoub Pasha Artin, Chakour Pasha, Boghos Pasha Nubar, Gallini Pasha, and Paterson Bey left for Cairo last night.

Captain J.B. Eustace, R.N., of H.M.S. Fox, and Commander A.R. Hulbert, R N.. of H.M.S. Proserpine, accompanied by Mr. V.J. Hughes- Laferla, British Pro-Consol at Suez, paid an official visit to Ibrahim Halim Bey, Governor of Suez, yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. G. Scott-Dalgleish have return- ed from Europe and are staying at the Graud Continental Hotel, Cairo.
Mr. G.D, Hornblower, inspector to the Mi- nistry of the Interior, will return from leave on the 30th Inst
Lieutenants R. Pigot and A.H Vivian, 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade have been granted leave of absence until November 15.
Mr. C. Meimarachi, managing director of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., was among the large somber of passengers who arrived last night by the B.S. Schleswig

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
ARRANGEMENTS FOR THURSDAY.
div.p: As previously announced, H.H. the Khedive will leave Alexandria for Cairo on Thursday next by a special train starting from Moharrem Bey terminus at 7.30 a.m.

A guard of honor, composed of three offioere and 100 non-commissioned offioers and men of the 7th Battalion, with the battalion co- lours and the Infantry Band, will line up at the station at 7.10 a.m. to await the arrival of his Highness, and as the train moves off a salute of twenty-one guns will be fired.

On the arrival of his Highness at Cairo at 11.30 a.m. he will be met at the station by H. B. the Sirdar, who will be supported by all officers of the Egyptian Army of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards, who are not on doty, and the guard of honor will be composed of three officers and 100 non-com- missioned officers and men of the 8rd Battalion with the battalion colours. As the train moves into the station the Cavalry Band will play the Khedivial national anthem and a salute of twenty-one guns will be fired.

On the same day her Highness the Khedivah will leave Montaiah Palace station at 7.40 a.m, and will arrive at Koubbeh Palace station at 12.10 p.m. A salute of 21 guns will be fired on the departure of the train from Montazih and also on its arrival at Koubbeh.

On the occasion of his return to Cairo, and of the beginning of the month of Rama- dan, his Highness will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace on the 1st Ramadan. The order in which visitors will be received will appear in to-morrow’s issue.
His Highness held a largely attended recep- tion at Ras-el-Tia Palace this morning previous to his departure for Cairo.

Persons honored with an invitation to be present on the railway platform on the occasion of tho Khedive’s departure for Cairo on Thurs- day aro requested to be there by 7.15 a.m. Their carriages must enter the station yard by the gate facing rue de la Qare and leave by the Moharrem Bey gate, to take up a stand in Nebi Daniel-atreet and Kom el-Dik. Consecutive numbers will be issued to guests on t hoir ontranoe to the station yard, so as to facilitate finding their carriages again.

div.head: PROMOTIONS.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive has been graciously pleased to make the following promotions on the occasion of their recipients’ retirement from the Government service :—
Moutemaiz.—Omar Louifi Bey, formerly sub-direotor of the Khedivial School of Law ; Mohamed Faozi Bey, formerly inspector ot buildings in the Ministry of Public Instruc- tion.
Sanieh.—Mohamed Inched Bey, formerly of the Finance Ministry.
Salissah. Mansour Messiba Effsndi, for- merly of the Finance Ministry.

div.head: NOTABLE NAVAL ENGINEER'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: Engineer Rear-Admiral Davies, who retired from the Navy lately after 45 years' service, took part in the Sudan operations of 1884, and it was he who discovered water springs near Berbera, which made garrison life at that place possible. He was engaged in river work in Burmab, and was, subsequently, the means of carrying out a number of valuable reforms in the engineering branch of the service.

div.head: P. & O. YACHT IN COLLISION. A telegram trom our Constantinople Corre- spondent yesterday states that the P. & 0. yacht Vectis has been in collision. The damage sustained by the vessel was only slight, but must neoessarily cause some delay to the ship.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The 8.3. Creole Prince left Manchester on Sunday, and is due to arrive at Alexandria, viA Tunis and Malta, on or about Nov. 7. The Moss liner 8eti sailed from Liverpool on Saturday afternoon and is due here on the 4th November with passengers, mail., and general cargo.
The Moss liner Menes arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning. The S.8. Egyptian Prinoe, from Manchester, left Malta yesterday evening, and is dae at Alexandria on Friday morning.

div.head: THE WAKES ADMINISTRATION. THE RECENT REFORMS.
div.p: Certain notes on the Wakfs Administration which appeared in a supplement to yesterday's "Official Journal" are of considerable interest, and contain a most interesting summary of the reforms recently introduced in an admini- stration which required considerable remo- delling. The Wakfs laboured under the disadvantages that beset all administrations of a quasi-religious and qoasi-finanoial nature. Religious conservatism opposed the least reform and, in this particular esse, the fact that British influence is predominant in Egypt oompels the reformer to advanoe cautiously, for fear of ezoiting religious controversy. In 1897 a new system of aocounts was introduced. Previously a separate account had been made up for each wakf, so that the administration had as many aooounta to draw up as it had wakfis to administer. This curious and burdensome system was based on the supposed impossibility of cover- ing the deficits of poor by the surpluses of rich wakfs, Moslem law forbidding the dis- posal of the revenues of one wakfs to the profit of another. To be consistent the admi- nistration should have limited the expenses of eaofe wakf to an amount which oonld be balanoed by its revenues. On the other hand, if for some aooidental or permanent cause the revenues of any wakf diminished or disappear-1 el, the reduction of its expenses or its total. suppression would have often involved the suppression of servioes and ceremonies of a religious arl charitable rature, and would have ruined a number of indigent or religious persons whose salaries or whose sustenance were alike drawn from this source. Accordingly an attempt was made to unify the accounts of all the wakfs of Egypt. j This was opposed by the Wakts Adminis- .* tration on the ground that the proposal was not in oonformity with the sacred law. A compromise was finally adopted under which the wakfs were grouped under various headings and the accounts of each group : combined, the resulting surplus forming a reserve fund to be employed according to the decision of the Khedive at the request of the director-general of the Administra- tion and in accordance with the advice of the Council of Administration or the Superior Council'of the Wakfs.

Now that this side of the administration has been put in order the question of the personnel has next to be settled, and a commission oomposed of the heads of the various sections of the administration presided over by ths sabdirector general and aided by the presence of a delegate from tie Ministry of Finance. Other 'seotions of the report deal with techniosl servioes, the exchange of“hikrs,”and with kuttabs, charitable institutions, aid mosques. With the latter seotions, which are of some public interest, ws propose to deal separately ; the rest are ot somewhat too j technical a nature for treatment, but we may give the conclusions of Harari Pasha, the author of the report: The Wakfs Administration should follow the following programme : 1. The completion of its system of accounts by the creation of a ‘capital’ aooount for both its urban and its rural properties. 2. The organisation of the personnel of its bureau. 3. The creation of a service of inspection. 4. Exchange of hikrs, the individual parts, in the properties posses red in common with individuals, and also the small scattered plots of cultivated land. 5. Exchange of buildings that have fallen in ruin, and the reconstruction of which would be too costly to pay. 6. The substitution of large cultivated | estates which can be easily guarded and administered. 7. To supp ly these estates with the most perfect system of irrigation and .drainage possible and to build agricultural lines on them and workmen’s houses, and buildings to let, furnished with the best modern hy- gienic appliances. 8. To take every measure ensuring that religious services be held under the most suitable conditions. 9. To see the prompt distribution of the surplus of private wakfs among the benefi ciaries immediately after the closure of the yearly aocounts. Finally, to be imbued with a sense of its philanthropic duties and do all that is in its power to aid the poor by the creation of dispensaries and by the development of elementary instruction among the poorer classes.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL'S FUTURE. SIR CHARLES PALMER’S VIEWS.
div.p: Sir Charles Mark Palmer, M. P., addressing the members of the Newcastle and Gateshead Chamber of Commerce, on the 13th inst, made an interesting statement with reference to the future of the Suez Canal.

Many of them, he said, were not, perhaps, felly acquainted with the fact that that Chamber km tho means of instituting reforms in the administration of the Suez Canal. It com- pelled the Canal controllers to take upon their board more directors representing the United Kingdom. It brought to the country a commit- tee to hear British grievances, previously to- tally ignored. He himself ventured to join the directorate, at the special invitation of M. Charles de Lesseps and Count de Lease pa. He spent a good many years on that body, and be was bound to say that the directors generally were inspired by the desire to make the Canal quite up to the requirements of the trade, and to do what was right to all nations. When they looked at the great volume of trade, however, and considered that even the sinking of a small merchant ship in the Canal would disturb traffic for a considerable period, they must Be led to c insider whether the Canal is likely to be in the future sufficient for til this extension of business. The new Treaty with Japan protected os from war in the But, and developed the great countries hitherto almost unknown. It opened new port*, new markets, new life of the highest importance, which must tend to the prosperity of the world. He there- fore thought that we would not entirely depend upon the Suez Canal in its present condition, and more especially did he feel that we would not continue to consider the dues exacted by the Canal other than onerous. He thought it possible that the Canal might be made an in Iternational Canal, free to all nations. In view of the great increase in the size and speed of ships, it seemed to him that, unless the dues were reduced and the Canal gave greater facilities for those vessels, undoubtedly the most economical course would be to go round the Cape. He thought that representations should be made with a view to securing a very large work of extension of the Canal.

div.head: THE PISANI CASE.
div.p: As we reported on Saturday, Pisani, the Maltese, who recently attempted to murder his mistress, Victoria, was operated on by Dr. Curling Haywood, and the bullet with which he is supposed to have shot himself was extracted. We learn that the man is progressing favorably, and that all danger of complica- tions is over. It is expected that he will be sufficiently recovered to be brought before the consular court on Friday, the day fixed for the and mined hearing, and the condition of his victim has improved so considerably that it is also likely that she will be able to give evidence.

Bail was granted to Pisani on Saturday afternoon, on the receipt of the doctor’s report of the improved condition of the woman, and the policeman under whose guard he was placed whilst in hospital has been withdrawn

div.head: ENGLISH CHURCH IN KHARTOUM.
div.p: A meeting was recently held at Tunbridge Wells in support of the scheme for the erec- tion of the English churchat Khartoum.Bishop Taylor Smith, the Chaplain General, presided, and in expressing bis deep sympathy with the movement, he said that though men might worship everywhere, yet to heathen and Moha- medan the finest church that could be built would be a visible sign of the reverence of Englishmen for their religion. The Ven. Archdeacon Gwynne sketched the history of the Christian Church on the Upper Nile, and claimed that these regions Were once Christian, and were to be won back to the faith. Incidentally, Archdeacon Gwynne spoke of the assistance and encouragement he had received in his labours as Army Chaplain at Khartoum from Sir Reginald Wingate and his staff. An appeal on behalf of the Building Fund realised nearly £30.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
FIRST HALFA TRAIN ARRIVES.
div.p: (From our correspondent)

Suakin (via Atbars), October 16. The British steamer Craigmore,' of Leith, arrived from England on the 14th inst., with about 9,000 rails for the Sallom-Port Sudan line. The line cannot be opened before Decem- ber, as the sleepers have not yet arrived from Australia. They are expected here by the end of this month.

Yesterday the first train from Haifa arrived here. It was composed of three saloon car-, riages and one sleeping car, and was drawn by an American-type engine. The passengers by this special train were Kaimakams Mid- winter Bey and Longfield Bey, both Assistant Directors of Railways at each end, Bimbashis Sower by and Lord, and the Hon. Pelham, engineer from the Haifa side. They leave to-day on their return to Atbars. I am sending my letter by the special train to Atbars, so that.it should be the first to be sent to Egypt overland from Suakin.
Suakin, October 19.

News has reached here from Port Sudan to the effect that the Italian contractors for the Government buildings there have struck work and refuse to go on with their jobs. M. Guido Corbetta, one of the contractors, has left Port Sudan altogether and gone to Cairo to take proceedings there. The remaining contractors are all Greeks, and are all doing well Work on the quarantine building is at a standstill. All the workman at both Railheads - who have used the pick and shovel for tie months and over, have received a gratuity of one month's salary from the Sudan Government Railways. The question as to whether the other employes and officials who have worked on the Suakin-Atbaras line will receive a gratuity is still pending.

div.head: THE ROYAL BERKS.
div.p: Now that the Royal Berks Regiment is leaving is for Khartoum, to give place to the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, a few words regarding the most glorious achievement of the regiment will not be amiss, and we cannot do better than quote an extract from an official despatch of Lt.-Gen. J. W. Primrose, C.S.L, who was in command of the Kandahar Field Force. He says :— "In forwarding the enclosed document, 1 would most respectfully wish to bring to his Excellancy, the Commander-in-Chiefs notice, the gallant and determined stand made by the officers and men of the 66th Regiment at Maiwand. I have it on the authority of a colonel of artillery of Ayoub Khan's army, who tree present at the time, that a party of the 66th Regiment, which he estimated at one hundred officers and men, made a most determined stand in the garden. They were surrounded by the whole Afghan army, and fought on until only eleven men were left, inflicting enormous loss on the enemy. These eleven men charged out of the garden, and died with their faces to the foe, fighting to the death. Such was the nature of their charge and the grandeur of their bravery, that although the whole of the Ghazis were assembled around . them, not one dared to approach to out them down. Thus, standing back to back, firing steadily and truly, every shot telling, surround- ed by thousands, these eleven officers and men died, and it was not until the last man had been shot- down that the Ghazis dare advance upon them. He farther adds that the conduct of these men were the . admiration of . all who witnessed it From an examination of the ground and from the position in which the bodies were found, I have not the least hesita- tion in stating that the account is true, and I think his Excellency will agree with me when I say that history does not afford any grander or finer instance of gallantry and devotion to Queen and country than that displayed by the 66th Regiment on the 87th July, 1880.”

“Maiwand Day” is kept annually by the regiment in a worthy manner, and residents of Alexandria will long have pleasant recol- lections of the hospitality which has been ex- tended to them on these occasions, daring the 2nd Battalion's stay here.

Sports form an outstanding feature of the celebration of Maiwand Day, and in this respect the R. Berks have a great deal to be proud of. The battalion gained an unusual number of sporting victories during the 1904-5 season. In the competition for toe Football League, the battalion won the shield open to the Army of Occupation. They also won the gold medals, for the Seaside competition, offer- ed by the Boulac Sporting Club, opes to all Egypt. In the Royal Military Tournament,held at Cairo, they won the Bayonet Fight i-g shield against all comers, achieving a gnat victory. At the Army of Occupation Rifle Meeting, the battalion met with great success In 1904 the G.O.C’s prize was won by the sergeants’ team, while in 1905 the Championship of Egypt was won by Sergt Wiggi’s of the 2nd Battalion. The Inter-company Challenge Shield for shoot- ing for the Army (abroad) was won by “D" Company of the 2nd Battalion. Finally, we may mention that the "Liebig" 50 guineas Cup offered for the beat shot throughout the mounted branches in South Africa during the war (1902) was won by Pte. Hancock of the 2nd Battalion (attached to the 10th Battalion Mounted Infantry).

These great achievements are due in a large measure to the vigorous manner in which the Sergeant Major of the battalion pushes sport of every description to the front The greatest support is offered by their popular command- ing officer, who mo it generously supplies the - funds to enable the men to indulge in cricket football hockey, bayonet fighting, shooting matches, boxing tournaments, open-air concerts, We wish the battalion a pleasant stay at Khartoum

div.head: LA COMMISSION DES LOCATAIRES
div.p: Nous avons reçu d’antres lettres à propos de la Commission des Locataires, mais il nous est impossible de continuer à insérer cette correspondance, là, polémique étant sortie du domaine public pour entrer dans le domaine privé. Nous regrettons que M. Mignot ait le premier employé des termes d’une violence exagérée' contre M. A. G. et que celui-oi se soit à son tour laissé entraîner contre M. Mignot à des insinuations qne nons considérons comme sans fondement aucun et qn’il regrette d’avrir laissé échapper dans la chalenr de la polém - que. (N.D.L.R.)
INFORMATIONS FINANCIERES

La question de l’intérêt de l’argent est à l’ordre dn jonr aussi bien en Egypte qn’cn Europe. Les journaux européens arrivés par le tout dernier oonrrier réflètent la préoccnpation qne leur donne cette question et expriment des craintes pour l’avenir.

Le marohé de Paris n’a pas en une meilleure allure la semaine passée qne la précédente. Ce n’est pas qne la cote ait été faible, mais il semble qne les dispositions si franchement con- fiantes dé naguère se soient qnelqne pen mo- difiées. Les r^KÜsations se sont poursnivies et ont presque ' constamment pesé snr les cours. An premier rang des préoccupations delà Bourse, se trouve la question de l’intérêt de l’argent On s’attendait, pendant les premières séances, à voir la Banque d’Angleterre procéder à une nouvelle augmentation du taux de l’escompte.

Ces craintes ne se Bont pas réalisées. Le taux de l’escompte n’a pas été augmenté à Londres la semaine passée, mais il pourra l’être la semaine prochaine, et cette appréhension para- ‘ lyse toute action nouvelle.

L’argent sera-t-il pins cher à la fin qu’su commencement du mois 1 On parait oroire à. des reports nn pen plus tendas, et l’on envi- sage oet enchérissement, comme une indication pour l’avenir. S’il en était ainsi, les positions jusqu’ici reportées pourraient donner lieu à des ventes assez suivies. Enfin, les questions ré- trospectives de politique extérieure, discutées dans la presse européenne, ont oréé un malaise contre lequel là Bourse n’a pas facilement réagi. Ou rie pense pas cependant qu’aucnn . incident sérieux puisse sortir de cette discus- sion tumultueuse.

Notons par oontre qne le comptant ne s’est guère laissé émouvoir par ces incidents : il a été sans doute moins actif qne précédemment, gardant ses disponibilités en vue des diffé rentes émissions annoncées, mais il ne s’est pa3 montré disposé à vendre les titres qu’il a jusqu’ici àbrerbés

En Egypte, dit le “Progrès,” le Banques en grande partie refusent d’ouvrir de nouveaux comptes d’avances sut titres et certaines mémo tirent la oorde à leurs clients en leur élevant le taux d’intérêts ou bien en leur limitant lerfr crédit.

Ge procédé de Banques, qui réservent leur dépôt pour l’aohat du change de la saison ootonnière actuelle, est la cause prinoipale de oette espèoe de orise ' financière qu’aggrave oette aimée davantage le renchérissement d’ar- gent octaepnné par les nouveaux emprunts russe et japonais et autres sur le marohé do Londres.

Dautre part, le nombre des valeurs, qui en valussent notre marohé, s’accroît de jour en jour au point de provoquerlun commencement de défiance. Mais en Bgy$â)on gobe tout et on restç impassible lorsque même on se voit littéralement volé, et pomme preuve vous aurez le résultat de la déb & ole de la société générale des Sucreries et Raffinerie. d’Egypte contre la quelle personne ne fera h moindre démarohe, si oen’est le groupe de défpasè des actionnaires Français. Qu’a-t-on fait contre les fondateurs de là Banque Industrielle d’Egypte, qui ont seuls profité de sa fondation, et de .la facilité avec laquelle ona zuinélapetite épargne! Rien. Il n’y a dono aucun espoiçhip voir le conseil d’administration et les direoreurs des Suoreries et Raffinerie d’Egypte, rendus responsables de lenr inqualifiable gestion, si la poussée ne venait de l’Europe.

div.head: MRS. MALAPROP
div.p: The dramatists who have created characters whose utterances are as familiar as household words, and whose names have added to the resources of the English vocabulary, are few indeed. If Shakespeare be omitted as ' hors concours,” Sheridan has few to compete with him as the creator of characters who are familiarly known to, and constantly quoted by, the world at large, though the quotation, as in all such cases, is frequently unconscious. Mrs. Malaprop, whose name has given that useful term “malapropism" to the language, is known of all men for her unequalled ability in pro- ducing a ‘‘nice derangement of epitaphs.” But Sheridan reaped, to some extent, where others had His mother, Mrs. Frances Sheridan, wrote play palled "A Journey to Bath," which has been supposed to be, in some sort, a foreshadowing of her son’s ‘ The Rivals but at least it contained a character named M s. Try foot, of a type on which Sheridan improved in Mrs. Malaprop.

But, of course, the real inspiration for the creation of this amusing blunderer is to be found, like so much else, in the pages of Shakespeare. Mrs. Malaprop is simply the lineal descendant of the immortal Dogberry. Dogberry, in “Much Ado About Nothing," does not occupy the stage so frequently as Mistress Malaprop in “The Rivals,” and, therefore, does not give utterance to such a wonderful variety of felicitous verbal blunders as bis descendant, but he is her undoubted original. And in the Shakespearean plays Dogberry does not stand alone It has been made a reproach to Shakespeare, indeed, that he is too fond of putting these misuses of words into his characters' mouths. The most devout Shakespearean is bound to admit that the poet paid tribute to no small extent to the prevailing taste tor absurd plays on words. Puns of a pitiful badness, ridiculous word- twisting, and absurd ‘conceits,"' as they were called, are to be found in some of his plays in irritating abundance. Although “not of her age, but for the time,” he was still the child of his age, and in his earlier plays especially, he tickled the ears of the groundlings like others of his craft. Apart from puns—of which a patient investigator has found more than a thousand in the plays—and the like verbal quips, malapropisms, or Dogberryisms," as they should here more properly be called, are to be found in plays which preceded “Much Ado.” For instance, in the ‘Merry Wives" Master Slender, when asked if he will marry fair Anne Page, rays: “If there be no great love in the beginning, yet Heaven may de- crease it upon better acquaintance, when we are married... but if you ray 'marry her,’ will marry her : that l am freely dissolved, and dissolutely.” And them three Dogberryisms can be paralleled elsewhere.

Still, these instances are only occasional, and Dogberry stands out as tbs undoubted father of malapropisms. Out of the abundance of modern examples there are few which cannot call Dogberry father, though the maternal re- lationship pf Mrs. Malaprop may be admitted. The choir who,on being questioned as to the preaching of a new curate, replied—“He robs his hands together all the time, for all the world as if be was performing his pollutions," was an unconscious Dogberry. The bereaved niece who said that if her old aunt had lived only two or three years more, she would have been a “centurion"; the old woman who re- marked that “ever” since I ate my front teeth by accident, I can’t rightly domesticate my food” ; and her Scotch companion who “likit Gound’s March of Marie Antoinette,” and who characterised a broad jest as 'a dooble St Andrew,” were all sealed of the tribe of Mrs. Malaprop.

All verbal confusions are not malapropisms. The man who had lost bis way in a great museum and asked to he shown the entrance ont; the civic dignitary who proposed the toast of “The Prince and Princess of Wales and the remains of the Royal Family"; and the judge who told the prisoner that be deserved condign punishment, suffered from verbal confusion of different kinds,bat were not true malapropism. The best malapropkuns are those which have a ' happy touch of truth about them. An excellent example is the remark of the servant girl who told an evening smaller that her mistress had gone to a “conversation only"—an ingenious and not untrue perversion of conversazione. Of the same kind was the confession of political faith odo6 made to the writer by an old man, jobbing gardener, that he was ' an old servatory.”

The original Mrs. Malaprop, who convulsed her audience at Covent Garden when “The Rivals" was produced in 1775, was Mrs. Green (Jane Hippisley). the daughter of John Hippisley, an actor well known in his day. Dibdin praises her droll humonr, and GeNest, who calLS her an excellent actress, says “correctness end vivacity -distinguished her performance." Mrs. Green made her mark as the original, representative, not only of Mrs. Malaprop, but of Mrs. Hardeastle in Gold- smith’s “She Stoops to Conquer,” and of the title character in Sheridan's "The Duenna.” Since her day many have been the actresses who have delighted audiences with Mrs. MalapropV ingenious perversions. Few, however, can have had such an absurd adventure as once befell Mrs, Poynter, a member of Buckstone’s once famous Hay market company, who on one occasion played Mrs. Malaprop in a performance of “The Rivals, given at Windsor before Queen Vic- toria in the, early year of Her late Majesty’s reign. Mrs. Poynter was one of the last ladies to wear the old fashioned, eighteenth century hoop, and she wore it on this occa- sion, appropriately enough, on the stage. Un- luckily in the course of tho evening the wide- spreading,-Unyielding wooden shoop stuckfast in the narrow wing, and the stage was kept waiting for some minutes while Mrs. Malaprop was being extricated from her ridiculous posi tion.

Descendants of Mrs. Malaprop in mordern fiction and humorous writing nave been fairly numerous—Mrs. Brown, Mrs. Slipshod, Mrs Ramsbottom, and the rest—though there is not one of them who equals her ancestor. The latest of the family is a Mrs. Pettifer in Miss E. G. Hayden’s clever Berkshire novel, “Rose of Lone Farm.” which was published a few months ago. Mrs. Pettifer is a decided success.

div.head: HENRY IRVING.
AN APPRECIATION.
div.p: BY JOSEPH KNIGHT.

A few days ago England could boast the possession of the greatest actor of the present or many previous generations. There is not the slightest exaggeration in this statement. We have to go beyond the time of Kean, Talma, and the Kembles, to that of David Garrick, to fend a man intellectually his equal. In quarters in which old traditions survive, this statement will be received with hesitation and demur, if it is received at all. It is none the less inde- feasible, and demonstrably true. We will go farther, indeed, and maintain that in days, science apart, of mediocrities and “non- valeurs,” one of the few truly great man we could boast has disappeared.

In expository ability Irving has known and leaves behind him compeers and rivals. His elocution, unless, as in Becket and one or two ether recent performances, he kept a guard upon himself, was faulty, and not even too articulate. His method was uncertain, and he was too often insensible of the value of repose. When endeavouring, as in Lear, Othello, and the great tragic characters, to display the tragic frenzy, his voice was sometimes raucous and scarcely human. These things signified 1 little, and in the splendoar of his accomplish- ment will soon be forgotten. They were but spots on the disc of a sun.

Almost the greatest gift of the actor was his imagination, perception, illuminatory power. Of his art it might be said, as Portia said of Mercy, “'Tis mightiest in the mightiest." He might spare to othlfta, the faultless limpid ' speech, the heroic gesture, the splendour of bearing. He bad, indeed, "that within which passeth show." He could fill a character and , inspire it. with a mighty and puissant con- ception. The idea, as in Shylock, might con- ceivably be wrong. Accepting it, however, as the might of the actor not seldom compelled, it was magnificently realised, and among the figures that crowd open the memory, that of the tall bowed figure, the eye hateful and gleaming with scorn, and the incarnation of powerless malignity, pathetic, and almost dignified in its impotence, stands one of the foremost.

Irvings’s greatest triumph was his Hamlet What, indeed, have we to oppose against it ? It lacked youth, and was meditative and infirm rather than gusty and passion-swayed. When we compare it with all others, however, it stands pre-eminent,' unassailable. In the scene after the hurried flight of the guil y King, when Hamlet throws himself on the vacant throne he is never again to occupy, it was absolute electricity. Those with capacit to judge, and experience wherewith to compare, ' are forced to go back to Fechter in order to find anything to- set against it, and the com- parison is then between the brilliant and the august. Failing recollections of Fechter wo torn to modern actors, in whom personal advantage and technique supply the place of inspiration. His Louis XI. remains the most sinister and fateful of his chara tera. His con- ception was wholly different from, and not quieter, than that of Charles Kean ; and was more varied, more estate, more malignant, but not more deadly. Mathias, the character in which he first showed the world on what it bad to count, and with what it had to deal, is, of course, an unsurpassable psychological study, the memory of which will never pass away. The keenest German students were stagger- ed by his Mephistopheles, which, indeed, outran accepted tradition. -It was nevertheless a profoundly stimulating if not altogether satisfactory interpretation, We have to recall also ‘‘Richard the Third," in which all that was most grimly sardonic and acrid in his honor showed itself. In more than one respect this performance stood fore- most "Robert Macaire," again, with its mingled gifts, and “Becket,” with its exquisite modulation, rise in the memory to show us what a loss w. have sustained, and how wide was the actor’s range, covering everything be- tween beauty and terror.

The charm of his manner, affectionate and occasionally playful and a trifle derisive among I his intimates, will not be forgotten by those who had the covetable honor of, his friendship. Staunch and loyal to those he loved, generous and ever magnificent of parse, using the word in its fall sense, in hospitality, he stood alone and apart, a man whose place in affection, admiration, and love is never to be filled.

div.head: FRENCH TRIBUTES
M. COQUELIN’S EULOGY.
div.p: After threading my way through a crowd of enthusiasts blocking the stage-door of the Gaite round M. Constant Coquelin’s motor- car, and passing by Roxane’s bower on the boards (says the "Daily Telegraph’s Paris Correspondent), I found the famous actor in his dressing-room preparing to make up for this evening’s performance of the ever-fresh “Cyrano” hardly an hour and a half after washing off the paint of the matinee. He at once explained with what deep sorrow he had heard of his old friend's death.

“I did not merely know him; we were not mere fellow-actors and comrades of the boards. We were friends, real friends, of a good deal more than twenty years’ standing. Yet, strange ly enough—and this by the way, is a remi- minscence I have not recalled to anyone for many a year we began by arguing together in print. There was some discussion between us in the early eighties, and published corres- pondence, mine coming out in some American paper, We had never met then, and when we

did meet over twenty years ago, we hit off at once, and remained close friends ever after. I can’t tell you how deepy I feel Irving’s passing away. How many long and valuable talks we have had, talks from which, each of us learnt to know more of the other, and of each other’a art, and from which 1 learnt more and more every time to admire and love Irving’a charac- ter. He was a delightful, a noble, an exquisite man. His charm was not mere courtesy ; it was true, genuine nobleness of character. He felt rather sadly the end of the Lyceum. Very deeply, in fact But he bore what was a poignant grief to him with admirable, with noble philosophy. His melancholy, when he was melancholy, was generous and large-hearted, for he knew not what bitterness was. But these last few months he was gayer and happier again. The great success of his Drury Lane season was a great joy to him. I was deeply glad of his success for his sake—and for the credit of the public.

“Yes, my old friend was a great heart, one of the chosen, I will say, an ame d’elite, a genuine Ame d’artiste, that is all that is no- blest. I feel his loss terribly. His friendship towards me never failed. On every single occasion when I went over to set in London I invariably found in my dressing-room on my first night a telegram of heartfelt good wishes. He was good and kind and generous unfailingly. Only last Friday I had the visit of two charm- ing English girls,daughters of a friend of Irving ' au'l of myself, and we talked for a long time , together about our friend. That was the very day of his death. Of course, I saw him in all hia parta—Hamlet, Macbeth, Charles I., Becket, and a boo re more. About ‘The Bells’ we disagreed to a certain extent. But in Irving’s acting one could criticise but a detail here and there. The ensemble was always great, always intensely interesting and valu- able. Criticisms were swamped when one looked at the creation as a whole.

“And what immense benefits the English ! stage owes him in every way I What wide and profound intelligence he had, with im- mense artistic and literary knowledge, and, of course, the instinct of his art. Above all, be was a great heart, and his friends will never see his like again. When is the funeral ? If only I could find the time to go over ! I would leave everything bat my duty here to go. I might try—yet, no. I cannot do it I am not only a soldier on duty here, I am, as it were, in the thick of the battle, and I cannot desert ' even fo- him. But again, I can’t tell yon how deeply I feel his loss." The dresser uttered a warning word. It was time for M. Coquelin to put on his war paint, and Cyrano’s grey felt, with the strag- gling feather, which lay on a chair by his side.

div.head: TURKEY AND THE POWERS.
div.p: Turkey still refuses to have anything to do with the new international scheme for the financial control of Macedonia. The patience of the Powers is nearly as inexhaustible as the obstruction of the Porte, but by this time, if they are really in earnest, its limits most almost hare been reached. The collective Vote of the six Embassies, to which the Porte was just replied with a refusal, represents positively the fourth effort on the part of the Powers to secure the adhesion of the Sultan. The first demand was made in May. In their fourth and last communication, on September 25, the Ambassadors pointed out that the foreign delegates appointed as controllers would arrive at Salonika on October 1, and asked that the necessary instructions to the provincial authorities should be given without delay. The delegates are now arriving at Salonika, where they will meet the Russian and Austro-Hungarian civil agents and confer with them on the programme of their labours. The Powers have disregarded the Porte’s con- tinued protests. They are probably wise in so doing. The presence of the international delegates in Macedonia may do not a little to convince the Turks that business is seriously intended, and that Europe means to have its way. If they continue their obstruction, they cannot do to any longer without challenging an open conflict with the Powers, and this would be neither prudent nor characteristic. Turkey prefers obstruction in the shade, and she has played her part so far with all her unfailing instinct for pure comedy. She has represented herself to the Powers, according to custom, as one who was only too ready to oblige, and who has, in fact, already given the last proofs of an obliging disposition in yield- ing to repeated and exorbitant demands from the Powers. All that she reserved for herself under the Murzsteg scheme was the sovereign rights of the Sultan, and now, she contends, the Powers are intruding upon these. The question really to be decided is whether this recalcitrance of Turkey means anything more than it has meant on previous occasion. Every time a reform has been broached the Porte has come forward with the same old story, and every time it has yielded in the end. S0, we imagine, it will eventually yield on this financial question, provided that the Powers show unmistakably that they mean to carry it through. Reports from Constantinople are not, however, although encouraging, and unless there is real unanimity of action as well as of language the Sultan will hold out. There is nothing over which Abdul Hamid keeps more jealous guard than the finances of his Empire. He may therefore be expected to resent the financial control of Macedonia by the Powers hardly less than he would resent its political dismemberment.

It is a strangely short-sighted policy on the part of Turkey not to accept and co-ope- rate in the programme of the Powers. In the last year or two Macedonia must have proved a most mostly possession to the Sultan. He has bad to spend large sums on mobilis- ing troops and patting down disorder the country has been absolutely impoverished ; and there has been the farther menace of a possible Bulgarian war. All his measures have been quite incapable of remedying the situation, and if he is left to himself the results will always be the same. It is the inherent weakness of the Turkish adminis- tration which is responsible for all the trouble in Macedonia. Being unable to govern the country in any other way, the Sultan pursues his plan of playing off one race and one Church against another ; and in the levying and assessment of taxes bis agents resort to extortionate abuse which permanently retards the development of the country. The amount of wastage which goes on must be enormous, and experience shows that there can be no remedy for this except some mea- sure of European control. We do not pretand that the task before the delegates is an easy one. One of the first and moat difficult steps they will have to take is to decide precise- ly what powers they require to carry out their task ; and the next step, perhaps not less difficult, will be to obtain them. No farther improvement in the state of Mace- donia seems possible without some such scheme as the Powers have devised, and it is hardly necessary to say that public opinion in this country will support His Majesty’s Government in any joint measures that may be needed to secure the compliance of the Porte. (“Times”).
